title: How to Download Project 64

steps.headline: Make sure you meet the system requirements.
steps.description: The recommended specifications are an Intel Pentium 3 1.5Ghz or higher, at least 512MB of RAM, and nVidia GeForce FX or later, and at least 1GB of hard disk space. Project64 is a Windows program. Most computers released since 2009 should be able to run the emulator with little issue.

steps.headline: Download the latest version of Project64.
steps.description: Older versions are available for interested users.

steps.headline: Close extra applications.
steps.description: In order to get the best performance out of the emulator, close any programs that you don't need active. Make sure all the latest drivers are installed on your computer. Finally, defragment your hard drive.

steps.headline: Run the setup program.
steps.description: Run the downloaded setup file. Tell the installer where you would like the Project64 program files installed. For most users, the default location will work fine. Continue to click Next to proceed with the installation. If you don't want to install any of the additional software that comes with Project64, be sure to uncheck the boxes before proceeding with the installation.

steps.headline: Run Project64.
steps.description: You can find the program in the Start Menu. The first time you run the program, you will need to choose a language.

steps.headline: Point Project64 to your ROM files.
steps.description: Click File to choose the folder that your ROM files are located in. ROM files can be either uncompressed or compressed in .zip format. There can only be one ROM in the .zip file. ROMs must not be hacked or truncated, or they will not work. Use a ROM verification program in order to ensure that your ROMs are valid. These are available for free online.

steps.headline: Learn your way around the program.
steps.description: You can load ROMs using the file menu. The Options menu will let you set your video, sound, and controller configurations.

steps.headline: Configure your inputs.
steps.description: In the Options menu, select Configure Input. This will let you set what key on the keyboard is assigned to what controller function. You can also setup a PC game controller to act as an N64 controller.

steps.headline: Play a ROM.
steps.description: When a ROM is loaded into the browser, you can double-click it to start playing. If the ROM is a valid file, it should begin playing. Take note of how well or poorly it runs. Make settings to adjust the playback of the ROM.

steps.headline: Adjust your video settings.
steps.description: In the settings you can adjust resolution, anti-aliasing, and more. Lowering the resolution may increase performance at the expense of visual clarity. Anti-aliasing will smooth out the images, but will lead to worse performance on older systems. Mess around with the advanced settings to find a configuration that runs best on your machine. If you need to, you can reset the settings to default.

text: Download Project64 Make sure you meet the system requirements. The recommended specifications are an Intel Pentium 3 1.5Ghz or higher, at least 512MB of RAM, and nVidia GeForce FX or later, and at least 1GB of hard disk space. Project64 is a Windows program. Most computers released since 2009 should be able to run the emulator with little issue. Download the latest version of Project64. Older versions are available for interested users. Install Project64 Close extra applications. In order to get the best performance out of the emulator, close any programs that you don't need active. Make sure all the latest drivers are installed on your computer. Finally, defragment your hard drive. Run the setup program. Run the downloaded setup file. Tell the installer where you would like the Project64 program files installed. For most users, the default location will work fine. Continue to click Next to proceed with the installation. If you don't want to install any of the additional software that comes with Project64, be sure to uncheck the boxes before proceeding with the installation. Run Project64. You can find the program in the Start Menu. The first time you run the program, you will need to choose a language. Point Project64 to your ROM files. Click File to choose the folder that your ROM files are located in. ROM files can be either uncompressed or compressed in .zip format. There can only be one ROM in the .zip file. ROMs must not be hacked or truncated, or they will not work. Use a ROM verification program in order to ensure that your ROMs are valid. These are available for free online. Use Project64 Learn your way around the program. You can load ROMs using the file menu. The Options menu will let you set your video, sound, and controller configurations. Configure your inputs. In the Options menu, select Configure Input. This will let you set what key on the keyboard is assigned to what controller function. You can also setup a PC game controller to act as an N64 controller. Play a ROM. When a ROM is loaded into the browser, you can double-click it to start playing. If the ROM is a valid file, it should begin playing. Take note of how well or poorly it runs. Make settings to adjust the playback of the ROM. Adjust your video settings. In the settings you can adjust resolution, anti-aliasing, and more. Lowering the resolution may increase performance at the expense of visual clarity. Anti-aliasing will smooth out the images, but will lead to worse performance on older systems. Mess around with the advanced settings to find a configuration that runs best on your machine. If you need to, you can reset the settings to default.
